Description: Oval, transparent rock crystal scaraboid with a domed back. Incised design including single-line border and field dividers. Intermediate between a three-register and a nine-compartment layout; the tops and bottoms of the vertical field dividers consist of 'ankh' signs. Four-winged beetle in central compartment, uraei with coiled tails on both sides; seated anthropomorphic, falcon-headed Horus figures in top and bottom compartments, each holding a malformed 'ankh' or 'maat' sign; empty "corner" compartments; letters of inscription, three of them inverted, added in empty spaces. Chipped.
Curator's comments: The iconography of our seal led some students to define it as Phoenician (e.g. Benz 1972, 366-367). The script could also be Aramaic or Ammonite, while the combined components of the name are better known in Ammonite than in Phoenician or Aramaic. Bibliography: Benz, F. L. 1972. 'Personal Names in the Phoenician and Punic Inscriptions'. Rome: Biblical Institute Press.
